metadata.title: Tableau: Unleashing the Power of Visual Analytics | by Mubarak Ganiyu | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Tableau: Unleashing the Power of Visual Analytics
metadata.description: About a month ago, I decided to challenge myself to learn more about data visualization. After multiple google searches to find the best data visualization tool, one product constantly stood out…

all_paragraphs: About a month ago, I decided to challenge myself to learn more about data visualization. After multiple google searches to find the best data visualization tool, one product constantly stood out, Tableau. I decided to install it and give it a try. As a student, I got a free license to use it. Then, I opened it and saw a big page asking me to connect to data or open workbooks. I did not know what to do next.

Confused, I consulted multiple online resources on how to use Tableau and I came across Ben Jones’ Communicating Data with Tableau: Designing, Developing, and Delivering Data Visualizations book. I highly recommend this book. It is very self-explanatory and useful for beginners who are interested in harnessing the power of data visualization with Tableau.

It taught me how to use both categorical and continuous data to create different kinds of charts such as bar chart, time series, scatter plots, box plots and geographical maps. Moreover, I learnt how to use features like filters, pages, marks and others to build high quality worksheets. Finally, I got the hang of utilizing the dashboard feature to build interactive visual dashboards that can be used to tell stories to people.

Tableau is known to be a fast analytics and rapid-fire business intelligence platform and there is no better way to describe it. My experience with Tableau over the last month has been nothing short of exciting. Below is a short summary of how Tableau is used to build beautiful interactive visual interfaces.

Unlike Python, R or any other data science programming language, Tableau does not require you to run lines of codes in order to load data, transform them and create plots. It’s very straightforward once you get used to it. You just have to upload the data by connecting Tableau to a server or a local file. Once the data has been connected, you get access to a worksheet and start building charts.

Another aspect that I love about Tableau is the fact that I can easily build my charts by dragging fields from the table section and integrating them with the features used to create the worksheets. The features that are essential to building worksheets are columns, rows, filters, marks and pages.

Immediate changes can be spotted on the worksheet as someone attempts to move the fields or manipulate the features. I can also change my chart by using the show me function. I no longer need to edit my code and re-run it and wait in order to get a different output. It is constantly changing as you work with it.
In the graph above, changes were made by removing the green bar containing income under the marks section and replacing it with population within a matter of seconds.

After building multiple worksheets in the workbook, they can be combined to build a dashboard. The dashboards on Tableau can be made interactive however you see fit. As the audience/presenter interacts with the dashboards, the dashboards draw insights or show activities within the charts. This makes the dashboards useful in telling stories or providing high quality information.

Once the dashboard has been built, the user can decide to share it with other members of the Tableau community on Tableau Public. This is done by creating a Tableau Public account and using the server function on the page to connect the dashboard to Tableau Public by logging in with your credentials. Once the dashboard has been uploaded, details about the dashboard can be added as well.

Tableau is a beautiful platform that I have learnt how to use over the past month and I am going to be using in the future. Using it has made me enthusiastic towards learning how to use other data science or data visualization tools. Above all, I am glad to have met Tableau.

Below is a video I made by recreating Hans Rosling’s famous video, The Joy of Stats. It shows how life expectancy and income has varied for different countries from 1800 till today. I used my knowledge of Tableau to build a scatter plot of Life Expectancy vs Income and make an interactive dashboard.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Writing articles centered around Data Science. Github profile: https://github.com/MUbarak123-56
